Rose and Yogurt Panna Cotta Recipe | Bon Appétit

I never had anything like it in the States: a milkshake with rose syrup, pistachios, raisins, and crunchy noodles. I loved it. For the restaurant, I wanted to put all those flavors into a dessert.” This unconventional panna cotta uses tangy yogurt in the base, which helps offset the sweetness of the rose syrup.Ingredients8 servings½cup raw pistachios1envelope unflavored powdered gelatin (about 2½ tsp.)1½cups plain Greek yogurt1Tbsp. rose syrup1¼cups heavy cream, divided½cup sugar1Tbsp. basil seeds (tukmaria) or chia seeds (optional)½cup golden raisinsBlackberries (for serving; optional)PreparationStep 1Preheat oven to 350°. Toast pistachios on a rimmed baking sheet, tossing once, until golden brown, 7–9 minutes. Let cool, then coarsely chop. Set nuts aside.Step 2Whisk gelatin with ¼ cup water in a small bowl to combine. Let sit 15 minutes.Step 3Mix yogurt, rose syrup, and ½ cup cream in a medium bowl to combine. Heat sugar and remaining ¾ cup cream in a small saucepan over medium, stirring often, until mixture is hot and sugar is dissolved, about 2 minutes. Whisk in gelatin mixture, then pour into yogurt mixture and whisk to combine.Step 4Divide panna cotta mixture among eight 4-oz. ramekins, small bowls, coffee cups, or any small vessel you’d like to use for serving. Place on a rimmed baking sheet and chill until set, at least 2 hours.Step 5If using, scoop a spoonful of basil seeds into a small bowl; pour in water to cover. Let sit until gelatinized, about 10 minutes.Step 6To serve, top panna cottas with basil seeds, raisins, a few blackberries, if desired, and reserved pistachios.Step 7Do Ahead: Panna cotta (without toppings) can be made 2 days ahead. Cover and keep chilled.How would you rate Rose and Yogurt Panna Cotta?Leave a ReviewTell us what you thinkReviews (2)Back to TopTriangleI haven't made this yet, but I do make a wafer cake that uses mascarpone and rose preserve in its layers.  Rose is such a wonderful flavor.  My great-grandmother made a salad of pink rose petals and lobster (this was a long time ago when lobster was still considered poor man's food) that I recreated a few years ago that was just delicious. Kudos to Bon Appetit having rose recipes. I will definitely make this soon as it has my favorite ingredients.arbpen9300Glendale7/30/2020I'm Italian, a real Panna Cotta purist. I was nervous about this recipe..... But I will definitely be making this again soon! This is the type of Panna Cotta you could eat for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. The Greek yogurt gives it such a unique taste and texture and the toppings match oh so well👌🏽.
